title: Jessica Simpson's Come On Over cover art font
content:
Based on "S", I think it has been digitalized even though it's some kind of hand-writing.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20130428015515im_/http:/typophile.com/files/5186DbvfOIL_4260._SL500_AA280_.jpg)

Jessica Simpson and Come On Over don't share the same type apparently.  
Any idea?
author: mydot2001

comments.content: The closest I can get you is [P22 Cezanne Pro](http://web.archive.org/web/20130428015515/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/p22/p22_cezanne_pro_ot/) (note alternates), [Lamar Pen](http://web.archive.org/web/20130428015515/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/three_islands_press/lamar_pen/), and [P22 Dearest](http://web.archive.org/web/20130428015515/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/ihof/p22_dearest_set/).

\> Larger image:

Jessica or the font? :)
Jessica is one ugly bimbo -- I prefer my women less synthetic. :^P ;^)

The song is surprisingly good anyway.

So should I give up the type identifying?

"Jessica Simpson" looks like a combination of several fonts.  
"J" and "S" are taken from [La Danse](http://web.archive.org/web/20130428015515/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/ihof/la-danse/la-danse/)  
"s" looks like [Voluta Script](http://web.archive.org/web/20130428015515/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/voluta-script/regular/)  
about the rest i am not sure
The p and the a are from Texas Hero.
Why did the cover design took the pain to diversify the types?
